On 11/30/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
>
> I'll second that.  Cons=
traints make a lot of things very nice--I'm
> particularly proud of this, a=
dapted from some GUI testing code:
>
> assertThat(valueOf(button).isEnabled=
(), eventually(eq(true)));


I don't know, I still have mixed feelings abou=
t this approach.  Although I
agree this particular example does read well, =
it's still extra verbose (e.g.
the "eq" statement) and I'm not completely c=
onvinced that to a programmer,

assertTrue(valueOf(button).isEnabled())

is=
 that much harder to read.

Anyway, my experience with this kind of literat=
e assertions is that it
scales very poorly as soon as you try to assert mor=
e than a simple equality
or a boolean, and in the end, you're probably bett=
er off simply writing a
method assertButtonIsEnabled(enabled) which, in my =
opinion, is the most
readable of all.

-- 
C=E9dric
http://testng.org
